title: Alcohol consumption, life course transitions and health in later life
abstractText:
Relatively little is known about the patterns of drinking in later life, the risk factors associated with excessive drinking at older ages and the relationship between drinking and other health conditions.

This study with explore the stability of drinking at later life and the key events that are associated with changes in drinking patterns. Based on analysis of the English Longitudinal Study of Ageing, a study, which collects data on the health, economic position and quality of life of people aged over 50 and their partners, cross-sectional analysis of this data will establish the main patterns of drinking in later life and the risk factors associated with binge drinking (excessive drinking on one particular day) and drinking in excess of the recommended weekly limits.

The life history data will be used to identify past events and transitions that may be associated with later changes in drinking behaviour. This analysis will investigate the dynamics of the relationship between changes in alcohol consumption and health conditions and how these are associated with life course transitions and past experiences.
